case_vignette:
A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter for a 1-week history of right leg weakness, unsteady gait, and multiple falls. During the past 6 months, he has become more forgetful and has sometimes lost his way along familiar routes. He has been having difficulties operating simple kitchen appliances such as the dishwasher and coffee maker. He has recently become increasingly paranoid, agitated, and restless. He has HIV, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His last visit to a physician was more than 2 years ago, and he has been noncompliant with his medications. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 152/68 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. He is somnolent and slightly confused. He is oriented to person, but not place or time. There is mild lymphadenopathy in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal areas. Neurological examination shows right lower extremity weakness with normal tone and no other focal deficits. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 3,600/mm3
Platelet count 140,000/mm3
CD4+ count 56/µL
HIV viral load > 100,000 copies/mL
Serum
Cryptococcal antigen Negative
Toxplasma gondii IgG Positive
An MRI of the brain is shown below.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing weakness in my right leg, unsteady walking, and I've fallen several times over the past week.
Have you experienced any numbness or tingling in your right leg?
No, I haven't felt any numbness or tingling, just weakness.
Do you have any medical conditions or are you taking any medications that I should know about?
Yes, I have HIV, high blood pressure, and type 2 diabetes, but I haven't been taking my medications regularly.
Do you have a family history of neurological conditions or any history of stroke in your family?
I'm sorry, but I don't have that information.
Based on your symptoms and medical history, it's important to undergo a neurological examination. I advise you to seek urgent medical attention.
